subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted that based on the historic currency manipulation by China, it is now even more obvious to everyone that Americans are not paying for the tariffs and that China is paying. Trump also stated that China has always used currency manipulation and is intent on continuing to receive the hundreds of billions of dollars they have been taking from the US with unfair trade practices and currency manipulation. (Twitter)

US Senate Minority Leader Schumer said he wants US President Trump to label China an FX manipulator as they have been manipulating their currency before President Trump took office. (Newswires)

China doesn't rule out the option of placing tariffs on US agricultural products that it purchases after August 3rd and Chinese firms have paused the purchase of US agricultural products, according to state media. (Newswires)

China State Planner said US accusations that China has not bought US farm products are false and that 2mln tonnes of US soybeans heading to China will be loaded this month, while it added that Chinese firms have applied for tariff exemptions on various US agricultural products purchased since July and that the sides agreed China will buy 14mln tonnes of soybeans from the US. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that in view of new tariff threat by the US side, the Chinese side has decided to suspend tariff exemption for US farms goods and Chinese enterprises have halted buying US farm products. (Twitter)

PBoC Governor Yi said China will not participate in competitive devaluation of the Yuan and that the currency will not be used as a tool to cope with trade tensions as well as other external disturbances, while Yi added the current exchange rate is at an appropriate level and that they will keep the Yuan exchange rate basically stable on a balanced and reasonable level. (Newswires)

Beijing are to announce 'something new' regarding Hong Kong on Tuesday, although an official stated that Beijing's position is largely unchanged. (SCMP)

Pakistan said they will exercise all possible options after India have revoked special status for the Kashmir region. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

European diplomats have been informed that UK PM Johnson has no intention to renegotiate the Brexit agreement and a no-deal is the "central scenario", while reports added that UK’s new chief Europe adviser David Frost is said to have sought discussions on how negotiations could be renewed after the UK crashes out. (The Guardian)

UK Opposition Labour Leader Corbyn said he will call for an 'early' confidence vote in UK PM Johnson, with this to be undertaken 'when we can win it' and it would be at 'appropriate very early time'. Corbyn added that the PM appears to be trying to slip a no-deal Brexit through, past both parliament and the public in general, while the confidence vote will be called when the UK Parliament returns from summer recess. (Newswires)

  • UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Jul) 51.4 vs. Exp. 50.2 (Prev. 50.2). (Newswires)
  • UK Composite PMI (Jul) 50.7 (Prev. 49.7)
  • EU Markit Services Final PMI (Jul) 53.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)
  • EU Markit Composite Final PMI (Jul) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.5)
  • German Markit Services PMI (Jul) 54.5 vs. Exp. 55.4 (Prev. 55.4)
  • German Markit Composite PMI (Jul) 50.9 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Confidential UN Report stated that North Korea stole approximately USD 2bln from banks and cryptocurrency exchanges via cyberattacks to fund WMD programmes, while it alleged that North Korea continued to develop its nuclear/missile programme despite diplomatic efforts. (Newswires)

Iranian Atomic Energy Spokesman said Iran are to take the third step in reducing commitments in one month If European signatories to the nuclear deal fail to uphold commitments, while it was also said that Iran has reduced its commitments to nuclear deal by having over 130 tonnes of heavy water and over 300 kilos of enriched uranium. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin said it is essential to resume full-scale talks with the US regarding strategic nuclear security after the INF treaty's demise, while he added that Russia will be forced to develop short/intermediate range missiles if the US does so. (RIA)

 

US

Fed Senior Loan Officer Survey stated bank lending standards and demand for commercial and industrial loans from large firms were unchanged but eased for smaller ones in Q2, while banks tightened their standards on credit card loans but auto and housing loans standards were unchanged. (Newswires)

Fed's George (voter, hawk) said the best we can do is monitor market developments and watch how they unfold. (Newswires)

  • US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (Jul) 53.7 vs. Exp. 55.5 (Prev. 55.1). (Newswires)
  • US Markit Services PMI (Jul) 53.0 (Prev. 52.2)
  • US Markit Composite PMI (Jul) 52.6 (Prev. 51.6)

 

MARKET RECAP

Last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump, the retaliation from China and a collapse in the yuan through the 7.00 handle triggered further global risk off, which resulted US stocks falling across the board. The tech sector, with its greater exposure to trade frictions with China, was worst hit. The FANG Index (of Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL)) sunk to near two-month lows, whilst the PHLX Semiconductor Index, which includes names such as Micron Technologies (MU), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and  Intel (INTC), moved below July lows. Other notable stocks with China exposure, including Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Skyworks Solutions (SKYW) also underperformer. The energy sector was pressured by lower crude prices and financials pressured by lower yields. Construction metals miners, including Alcoa Corp (AA), United States Steel Corp (X) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) were dragged lower as steel and aluminium prices fell off a cliff. Bucking the trend were precious metals miners, such as Barrick Gold (GOLD) and Newmont Goldcorp (NEM), as gold prices reached fresh YTD highs. Affiliated Managers Group (AMG) has saw some upside on reports that it had hired advisors to study a potential sale. Abiomed (ABMD) moved higher on the news of higher than expected rates within its final inpatient prospective payment system. Arms maker American Outdoor Brands (AOBC), opened higher after the mass shootings this weekend, as normally occurs when tighter regulations are mulled. Gaming names, including EA (EA), TakeTwo (TTWO) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI), were under pressure after US President Trump criticised video games, says too many are "gruesome" and need to be reduced immediately. Evercore made negative comments on Centene (CNC) and CVS (CVS), saying both are seen losing a Medicaid contract in Louisiana Evercore says winners could be UnitedHealth (UNH), Humana (HUM), and Anthem (ANTM). S&P 500 -3% at 2845, NASDAQ-100 -3.6% at 7416, Dow Jones -2.9% at 25718.

The Treasury curve bull steepened, with price action driven by risk-off flows, pushing Treasury yields down by between 10bps and 14bps across the curve. There was further buying in afternoon trade, after China had confirmed that state firms had stopped buys of US agriculture, and did not rule out sanctions on US ags in the future. Fed pricing has moved dovishly, with traders now seeing 111 worth of easing through the end of next year, from around 100bps of easing on Friday. A 25bps rate cut at the September meeting is priced with certainty, and there is now around 40% chance of the ‘double’ rate cut of 50bps at that meeting. Fed officials that have spoken have been quite circumspect, and hawkish George and dovish Brainard both indicated that they were monitoring the market. There are a host of other Fed officials on the slate for the week, and the desk will be paying particular attention to the dovish Bullard, who is due to speak on Tuesday; Bullard made the case ahead of the July Fed meeting that a 50bps cut was a bit too excessive. US T-note futures (U9) settled 31+ ticks higher at 129-27.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 5th August 2019: Risk-off as China allows USDCNY to slide passed 7.00
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar lower, Crude lower.
  • REAR VIEW: PBOC allows USDCNY above 7.0, causing risk-off; China doesn’t rule out placing tariffs on US ags, confirms stopped state buying; Fed’s Brainard, George monitoring markets; non-manufacturing ISM disappoints.
  • NEXT WEEK: Data: Japanese Household Spending, Australian Trade Balance & US JOLTS, Events: RBA Rate Decision & EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, Speakers: Fed’s Bullard & Harker, Auctions: UK GBP 3bln 2025 & US USD 38bln 3yr, Earnings: Walt Disney, Microchip, Emerson Electric, Deutsche Post.

 

* MARKETS WRAP: The day started off with a distinct risk-off tone after China allowed the yuan to weaken to over 7.00 vs the USD, resulting in flows into safe havens, and hitting the EMFX complex. US stocks opened in the red, the Dow by over 400 points lower, and then extended losses before stabilising to over 800 points in afternoon; tech led the losses, followed by financials as the Treasury curve bull-steepened, with energy and telecoms also performing very similarly. Oil was lower, with traders focussing on the potential hit to global demand growth as trade war tensions ramp up.

* CHINA: Risk sentiment was hit after China’s PBOC allowed the yuan to trade above the psychological 7.00 mark for the first time since 2008, which had previously been seen as a ‘line in the sand’ that Beijing was prepared to defend. The move followed the announcement of further tariffs on Chinese imports last week. The Chinese have also reportedly cancelled purchases of US agricultural goods, attacking two areas close to Trump’s heart (the dollar, and agriculture). China’s Global Times Editors confirmed these reports, saying “based on what I know, in view of new tariff threat by the US side, the Chinese side has decided to suspend tariff exemption for US farms goods and Chinese enterprises have halted buying US farm products.” China state media later confirmed that state companies had paused purchases of US agriculture, and did not rule out placing tariffs on US ags on purchases made after 3rd August. US President Trump took the opportunity to accuse China of currency manipulation, stating that it dropped the price of the currency to an almost a historic low, and that "it's called ‘currency manipulation.’ Are you listening Federal Reserve? This is a major violation which will greatly weaken China over time." Trump later continued his attack, accusing China of using currency manipulation to steal business from the US, and reiterated his claim that the US consumer was not ‘paying for the tariffs’; on which note, some desks have argued that in his belief that US consumers are not being hurt by tariffs on Chinese imports, Trump may be more inclined to increase them further. Trump’s calls to label China a currency manipulator once again drew the support of Democrat Senate Minority Leader Schumer, who has also called for such action in the past.

* YUAN ANALYSIS: The yuan weakened overnight to above 7.00 against the USD, for the first time in a decade, after the US' latest escalation of trade wars last week, where it announced fresh 10% tariffs on the remaining portion of Chinese imports (around USD 300bln worth); overnight, there were also reports that China had asked state buyers to halt US agriculture imports. The 7.00 level was previously considered a 'line in the sand' for the PBOC, which had kept it stable beneath that level recently. The move higher has resulted in a significant risk-off reaction in markets, where havens have found buyers, while more risk-on assets have been hit. There were previously also concerns that a move above the 7.00 mark could contribute to outflows from China. And the PBOC Governor reiterated that position in comments during the European day, stating that China will not engage in competitive devaluations. In that regard, the PBOC attempted to inspire some confidence, stating that the breach of 7.00 does not mean the yuan will not come back, and that it has the experience, confidence and capacity to keep the renminbi exchange rate fundamentally stable and at a reasonable and balanced level. Desks have also noted that the central bank has also recently supported business purchasing FX hedging products. And the PBOC has also advised enterprises not to speculate on yuan moves to profit from derivatives trading, since the yuan trend is difficult to predict, hinting that there may be more volatility ahead. The PBOC's response was somewhat predictable, since it doesn't want to be accused of manipulating the currency (China is on the US' monitoring list, but has not yet been labelled a 'currency manipulator'). Natwest, after speaking to clients in Beijing recently, said Beijing has made it clear the PBOC would use the fixings, its capital controls and possible some off-balance sheet transactions to manage the yuan's move lower, but would not run down their FX reserves dramatically as they did in 2015-2016. Desks note that China has gone after two areas close to Trump -- the currency, and agricultural purchases -- in its retaliation against the US announcement of further tariffs. Natwest says that if the central bank isn't willing to use their FX reserves aggressively then the move though 7.00 will be sustained and significant. This may support arguments that Trump could instruct the Treasury to intervene in FX to arrest the USD appreciation. Last week, the Fed also eased policy last week as insurance against any trade risks weighing on its outlook, and Trump seems to have manipulated the Fed into remaining accommodative in the months ahead. The breach of 7.00 underscores that global markets and policymakers will have to get used to a more market-driven CNY and the greater variability that comes along with that, Oxford Economics says. Building on that, SocGen notes that the CNY is second to the EUR in its weight in the Fed's trade weighted USD basket, and it also has the biggest weighting in the ECB’s trade weighted EUR basket. "For the euro, it’s another weight to bear as weaker trade hurts an economy without enough growth to cope with a stronger (trade-weighted) currency. For the US President of course, with his concerns about the dollar being too strong, it is going to be a source of significant irritation. The debate about US FX intervention is going to heat up significantly."

* US NON-MANUFACTURING ISM: The non-manufacturing ISM fell to a three-year low, falling to 53.7 from 55.1; the data suggests that the downturn seen in manufacturing is now spreading into the larger services sector. "A weighted average of the ISM indices is consistent with zero economic growth at the start of the third quarter" Capital Economics said, but added that it does not think that the economy is about to plunge into recession: "after all, payroll employment growth is still solid and other leading indicators, including initial jobless claims, show few signs of deterioration, but the ISM survey clearly supports our view that economic growth will slow sharply in the second half of this year." The headline was dragged by business activity, which fell to 53.1 from 58.2. New orders also slipped, signalling some cooling ahead. Employment was up slightly, but the read is slightly redundant seen as we have already got the NFP report for the month last week. "Regardless, there’s no denying that this is a weak report, and it also isn’t the only survey pointing to a sharp slowdown," CapEco says, "despite upward revisions to the final estimate released today, the July Markit composite PMI also points to a slowdown in GDP growth, to little more than 1% annualised." The consultancy notes that the weakness in the US economy has so far been concentrated in the export-focused manufacturing sector, but signs that this malaise is now spreading to the services sector will undoubtedly be a concern for Fed officials. "We had assumed that the next rate cut would be delayed until December, but the apparent slowdown in service-sector activity growth, the escalation of trade tensions with China and the continued sell-off in the stock market mean that the chances of a cut at the September FOMC meeting are rising rapidly."

* FX WRAP: Havens JPY, CHF and XAU caught a bid amid the risk-off after China’s yuan slid against the USD. The Buck, however, could not catch a bid, amid the spectre of potential USD intervention, an easing Fed, and a grim ISM non-manufacturing report. The EUR – which usually takes a hit on escalating trade tensions – was stronger, supported by US/EU Rate differentials; the yuan has the largest weighting in the ECB’s trade weighted EUR index, which has been supporting the EUR on Monday, while the USD weakness is also helping the single currency; in a sign of the EUR’s strength, EURJPY was actually higher, despite the yen rising against most other FX. The Antipodes and EMFX were also whacked on Monday.

* IRAN: Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif reiterated that Iran will walk away from the 2015 Nuclear Deal if needs be; more specifically, if Iran’s interests weren’t upheld. Zarif called on the remaining European signatories to make good on their commitments “to shield Iran’s economy from US sanctions” (e.g. by purchasing its oil). The Foreign Minister, who is considered one the least hawkish Iranian officials, said the US’ sanctions were “economic terrorism”, and feels like the US isn’t interested in talks, and Iran will never capitulate. Later on, an Iranian Atomic Energy spokesperson said provided the Europeans don’t hold up their end of the nuclear deal, Iran would take a third step in reducing commitments within a month, affirming that it has already reduced its commitments to the nuclear deal by holding over 130 tonnes of heavy water and breaching the 300kg stockpile limit of enriched uranium.

* BREXIT: UK PM Boris Johnson has no intention of renegotiating Brexit deal, EU was told according to the Guardian. A no-deal Brexit remains Johnson's 'central scenario', the chief Brussels envoy reportedly said. The news comes amid hardening evidence in Westminster that the government is expecting to crash out of the EU, the Guardian claims.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 31+ TICKS HIGHER AT 129-27. The Treasury curve bull steepened, with price action driven by risk-off flows, pushing Treasury yields down by between 10bps and 14bps across the curve. There was further buying in afternoon trade, after China had confirmed that state firms had stopped buys of US agriculture, and did not rule out sanctions on US ags in the future. Fed pricing has moved dovishly, with traders now seeing 111 worth of easing through the end of next year, from around 100bps of easing on Friday. A 25bps rate cut at the September meeting is priced with certainty, and there is now around 40% chance of the ‘double’ rate cut of 50bps at that meeting. Fed officials that have spoken have been quite circumspect, and hawkish George and dovish Brainard both indicated that they were monitoring the market. There are a host of other Fed officials on the slate for the week, and the desk will be paying particular attention to the dovish Bullard, who is due to speak on Tuesday; Bullard made the case ahead of the July Fed meeting that a 50bps cut was a bit too excessive. 

* WTI (U9) SETTLES USD 0.97 LOWER AT USD 54.69/BBL; BRENT (V8) SETTLES USD 2.08 LOWER AT 59.81/BBL: The ramp-up of US-China trade tensions has helped crude futures kick-off the week on the back-foot. As equity market sentiment dips, global demand concerns linger in the energy complex and places supply-side factors on the back-burner, at least for the time being; analysts at Citigroup see potential for downgrades in the approaching EIA, IEA, and OPEC monthly reports’ oil demand growth forecasts. It is worth highlighting the WTI/Brent Arb which has been narrowing in the past couple of months, it is currently approaching the USD -5.00 mark, a level which has not been seen since this time last year. There are several factors which are likely to be playing into the Arb narrowing such as decreased Brent demand as trade moves to other crude sources which rely less on shipping through the risk-laden Strait of Hormuz, as well as a recent string of large draws in US crude inventories providing tailwinds to WTI which have been accelerated by recent weather disruptions and growing US crude exports.

* S&P 500 -3% at 2845, NASDAQ-100 -3.6% at 7416, Dow Jones -2.9% at 25718. Consumer Discretionary -2.7%, Consumer Staples -2.7%, Energy -3%, Financials -3.3%, Health Care -2.4%, Industrials -2.8%, Information Technology -4.1%, Materials -1.9%, Telecommunication Services -2.9%, Utilities -1.5%.

* EARNINGS: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) outperformed the market after the co. reported decent net and operating earnings Y/Y. Jacobs Engineering Group (JEC) was buoyed after the co. beat on top and bottom lines and raised its FY EPS view. Tyson Foods (TSN) shot higher after the co. posted a beat on the bottom line and backed its FY EPS view, despite missing revenue expectations. WEC Energy Group Inc (WEC) advanced after the co. posted a beat on the bottom line and raised guidance. Loews Corp (L) fell despite posting a big beat on revenue expectations. ON Semiconductor Corp (ON) sunk on poor revenue and guidance.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump, the retaliation from China and a collapse in the yuan through the 7.00 handle triggered further global risk off, which resulted US stocks falling across the board. The tech sector, with its greater exposure to trade frictions with China, was worst hit. The FANG Index (of Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL)) sunk to near two-month lows, whilst the PHLX Semiconductor Index, which includes names such as Micron Technologies (MU), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and  Intel (INTC), moved below July lows. Other notable stocks with China exposure, including Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Skyworks Solutions (SKYW) also underperformer. The energy sector was pressured by lower crude prices and financials pressured by lower yields. Construction metals miners, including Alcoa Corp (AA), United States Steel Corp (X) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) were dragged lower as steel and aluminium prices fell off a cliff. Bucking the trend were precious metals miners, such as Barrick Gold (GOLD) and Newmont Goldcorp (NEM), as gold prices reached fresh YTD highs. Affiliated Managers Group (AMG) has saw some upside on reports that it had hired advisors to study a potential sale. Abiomed (ABMD) moved higher on the news of higher than expected rates within its final inpatient prospective payment system. Arms maker American Outdoor Brands (AOBC), opened higher after the mass shootings this weekend, as normally occurs when tighter regulations are mulled. Gaming names, including EA (EA), TakeTwo (TTWO) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI), were under pressure after US President Trump criticised video games, says too many are "gruesome" and need to be reduced immediately. Evercore made negative comments on Centene (CNC) and CVS (CVS), saying both are seen losing a Medicaid contract in Louisiana Evercore says winners could be UnitedHealth (UNH), Humana (HUM), and Anthem (ANTM).

subject: Daily FX Wrap: POTUS denounces China for devaluing the Yuan
content:
CHF/EUR/JPY

Although risk aversion has not reached new proportions or turned into a full-scale rout (yet), the traditional safe havens remain sought after with the Franc hovering around 0.9750 vs the Dollar and 1.0900 against the Euro, even though the single currency is actually slightly firmer compared to the Buck and perhaps gleaning more from the meltdown in EM currencies (or even SNB intervention as the Eur/Chf cross has bounced from circa 1.0865?) Moreover, technical impulses may be helping Eur/Usd continue its climb from 1.1105 through Fib resistance at 1.1174, the 21 DMA (1.1186) and eyeing 1.1200. However, the Yen has pared some gains within 105.80-106.67 parameters and also testing a key retracement level (106.06) as US Treasury yields bounce (marginally) from their lows.

DXY/CNH

The index has slipped a bit further from post-FOMC highs of 98.941 (also a new 2019 peak) amidst a ramp up in US-China trade wars and in wake of a weak US non-manufacturing ISM survey wot just under 97.500 at one stage. Meanwhile, President Trump has responded to the Cny and Cnh slide through 7.0000 and accused Beijing of currency manipulation only a few months after the last official US Treasury report (published around the end of May) did not label China as one of the nations that has used devaluation to its advantage. The PBoC insists the Yuan’s move well below the overnight mid-point setting (6.9225) was not orchestrated, but perhaps more poignantly added that it is at an ‘appropriate’ level, so not past the point of tolerance. Note, Usd/Cnh is currently just under 7.1000 vs 7.1087 at one stage and the Cny ended on-shore trade around 7.0352.

AUD/NZD

Although off worst levels within a 0.6805-0.6750 range vs its US counterpart the Aussie is still on the defensive ahead of the overnight RBA meeting, the aforementioned heightened US-China angst and China’s softer than forecast Caixin services PMI. Nevertheless, a dovish message from the Central Bank could well put the Aud back under pressure given option pricing indicating a 50 pip break even for the event and the early year flash crash base not too far away (0.6715). Conversely, the Kiwi has clawed back losses vs the Greenback between 0.6490-0.6542 and extended gains vs its Antipodean peer with Aud/Nzd slipping towards 1.0350 as a ¼ point RBNZ ease is fully priced in the for this week and the near term focus is on NZ jobs data later tonight.

NOK/SEK

The Scandi Crowns have also been hit by broad risk-off sentiment and the relative Euro strength noted above, with Eur/Nok fuelled by the downturn in crude as well as it rebounds to 9.9950+ and outpaces Eur/Sek at just over 10.7700 in percentage terms.

GBP

Sterling is swooning again on no deal Brexit risk as new UK PM Johnson reiterates that October 31 is set in stone as a departure date from the EU with or without a formal agreement. Cable is back near 1.2100 vs almost 1.2190 after a better than expected services PMI and Eur/Gbp has breached 0.9200 amidst some talk of possible fix demand (ie RHS orders).

EM

Contrasting fortunes for the Brazilian Real and Turkish Lira, as the former gets scant relief from the overall decline in risk appetite from latest reports about a vote on the Pension Reform Bill, possibly by midweek, but the latter outperforms on softer than anticipated CPI and CBRT tweaks to RRRs that are estimated to result in a Usd2.1 bn drain.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 5th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

5th August 2019

Last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump, the retaliation from China and a collapse in the CNH through the 7.00 handle triggered further global risk-off. China exposed firms in particular, including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Micron Technologies (MU), Johnson Controls (JCI) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), were under pressure in premarket trade. Other risk/trade sensitive sectors, including the tech and auto maker sectors, were under pressure, with the FANG index in particular suffering. Meanwhile, amid the risk-off triggered collapse in metal prices, mining names suffered, with only gold miners, including Newmont Goldcorp (NEM) and Barrick Gold (GOLD) bucking the trend as the safe haven metal hit fresh YTD highs.

DOW

Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) - Apple analyst Ming-Chi Kuo predicts that the 2021 iPhone could have both Face ID and Touch ID, with the expected supplier of the technology to be Qualcomm (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors). Separately, Kuo suggests that prices of Apple's iPhone won't go higher amid the trade war with China, saying the company will absorb most of the costs.

Intel (INTC) (Information Technology/ Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) and Lenovo have announced a collaboration to focus on convergence of AI, HPC (High performance Computing) to aid in problem solving for world problems.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) are reportedly in the lead to head WeWork’s upcoming IPO. Goldman Sachs Group (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) is also slated to have a leading role in the public offering.

Pfizer Inc.’s (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Phase 3 Rivipansel study, which evaluated the efficacy and safety of rivipansel in patients aged six and older with sickle cell disease, did not meet primary or secondary efficacy endpoints.

Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) – A gunman opened fire in a Walmart store in El Paso, Texas over the weekend, killing 20 and wounding several more. The incident is being treated as a domestic terrorist case. The co., which is the largest arms seller in the US, reportedly has no plans to stop selling arms or ammo after the incident.

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has temporarily stopped contractors from listening to its Google Assistant recordings, after the co. became aware of leaked data, reported Business Insider.

Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is to provide Alexa owners with the option of disabling “human reviews”, following reports that thousands of Amazon employees were listening in to Alexa recordings in order to improve the software.

Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has started adding its name to some screens on its Instagram this week, the first time the co. has indicated its ownership on the photo sharing platform.

S&P 500

subject: Nomura quants expect US equity futures to remain under significant systematic selling pressure
content:
• Risk-off in equities is spreading, but Nomura says it is a position adjustment by CTAs and other such trend-followers, adding that there is evidence that some other market participants (ultra-short-term traders and global macro hedge funds) are taking the contrarian step of averaging down.
  • "It appears that selling has not yet set off the sort of chain reaction in which the withdrawal from long positions by speculative traders leads to an allocation shift among investors with longer-term horizons," Nomura writes, "from this angle at least, many observers may be inclined to see the present selloff as a temporary, mild-to-moderate risk-off scenario similar to the May selloff."
  • But Nomura notes that its own measure of stock market sentiment has swiftly deteriorated in a way that looks quite different from what transpired in May. "In particular, an irregular pattern of deterioration in sentiment has taken shape, with stock market sentiment in the US and mainland China turning sharply downward." Nomura explains that at times like this, when sentiment momentarily falls to more than one or two standard deviations below its rolling average, it has often turned out after the fact that the market had been factoring in a slowdown or downshift in fundamentals.
  • "The US's imposition of the fourth round of tariffs on Chinese goods may indeed prove to be a game changer," the bank says, "and if sentiment fails to climb back to around risk-neutral, this week (5-9 August), there is good reason to worry that the global selloff in equities will metastasize from the present isolated position adjustments by technically minded investors into a market-wide pricing in of erosion in fundamentals." Nomura's quants also state that the sharp deterioration in our gauge of US stock market sentiment points to rapid deterioration in the balance of supply and demand.
  • Nomura says that the sell-off in US stocks seems to be mostly a matter of selling by investors following either trend-following strategies or strategies premised on the assumption of prolonged low volatility. "It appears that stocks are finding support in the form of bargain-hunting by investors following a short-term reversal strategy and investors whose strategies emphasize fundamentals," the bank writes.
  • However, Nomura says that the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ 100 have now both fallen below the breakeven lines for the outstanding long positions of trend-following algo investors; "the average cost of CTAs' net buying of futures since June corresponds to an S&P 500 reading of around 2,960 and a NASDAQ 100 reading of around 7,720. The declines in these indices may have thus forced CTAs into loss-cutting mode."
  • CTAs' net long position in S&P 500 futures is still only 25% smaller than it was at the 16 July peak, Nomura notes, and CTA's net long position in NASDAQ 100 futures is only 30% smaller than at the 11 July peak. "We therefore expect futures to remain under significant systematic selling pressure."

subject: ANALYSIS: USDCNY above 7.00 on trade war escalation and protectionism
content:
• YUAN WEAKNESS: The yuan weakened overnight to above 7.00 against the USD, for the first time in a decade, after the US' latest escalation of trade wars last week, where it announced fresh 10% tariffs on the remaining portion of Chinese imports (around USD 300bln worth); overnight, there were also reports that China had asked state buyers to halt US agriculture imports.
  • THE 7.00 LEVEL: The 7.00 level was previously considered a 'line in the sand' for the PBOC, which had kept it stable beneath that level recently. The move higher has resulted in a significant risk-off reaction in markets, where havens have found buyers, while more risk-on assets have been hit. There were previously also concerns that a move above the 7.00 mark could contribute to outflows from China. And the PBOC Governor reiterated that position in comments during the European day, stating that China will not engage in competitive devaluations.
  • PBOC TO BE ACTIVE: In that regard, the PBOC attempted to inspire some confidence, stating that the breach of 7.00 does not mean the yuan will not come back, and that it has the experience, confidence and capacity to keep the renminbi exchange rate fundamentally stable and at a reasonable and balanced level. Desks have also noted that the central bank has also recently supported business purchasing FX heding products. And the PBOC has also advised enterprises not to speculate on yuan moves to profit from derrivatives trading, since the yuan trend is difficult to predict, hinting that there may be more volatility ahead.
  • YUAN FIXINGS: The PBOC's response was somewhat predictable, since it doesn't want to be accused of manipulating the currency (China is on the US' monitoring list, but has not yet been labelled a 'currency manipulator'). Natwest, after speaking to clients in Beijing recently, said Beijing has made it clear the PBOC would use the fixings, its capital controls and possible some off-balance sheet transactions to manage the yuan's move lower, but would not run down their FX reserves dramatically as they did in 2015-2016.
  • USD INTERVENTION: Desks note that China has gone after two areas close to Trump -- the currency, and agricultural purchases -- in its retaliation against the US announcement of further tariffs. Natwest says that if the central bank isn't willing to use their FX reserves aggressively then the move though 7.00 will be sustained and significant. This may support arguments that Trump could instruct the Treasury to intervene in FX to arrest the USD appreciation. Last week, the Fed also eased policy last week as insurance against any trade risks weighing on its outlook, and Trump seems to have manipulated the Fed into remaining accommodative in the months ahead.
  • AFTER THOUGHT: The breach of 7.00 underscores that global markets and policymakers will have to get used to a more market-driven CNY and the greater variability that comes along with that, Oxford Economics says. Building on that, SocGen notes that the CNY is second to the EUR in its weight in the Fed's trade weighted USD basket, and it also has the biggest weighting in the ECB’s trade weighted EUR basket. "For the euro, it’s another weight to bear as weaker trade hurts an economy without enough growth to cope with a stronger (trade-weighted) currency. For the US President of course, with his concerns about the dollar being too strong, it is going to be a source of significant irritation. The debate about US FX intervention is going to heat up significantly."

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 5th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmly in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.4%] as the US-China trade narrative ramps up and USD/CNH went through the 7.00 handle
  • China has asked state run firms to halt US agriculture purchases, however the State Planner later rebuffed the US’ accusation that China has not purchased farm products
  • Fixed remains firmer, though of off session highs while the DXY continues to falter below the 98.00 mark
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Services and Composite PMI; US ISM-Non-Manufacturing PMI; New Zealand Unemployment

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lower across the board as the stock rout resumed from last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump and with retaliation from China in which it asked state-run purchasers to halt US agriculture imports, while a collapse in the CNH through the 7.00 handle also exacerbated the risk averse tone. ASX 200 (-1.7%) weakened with the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials front-running the declines, although gold names bucked the trend on the precious metal’s safe-haven status, while Nikkei 225 (-1.7%) was pressured by a firmer currency and several disappointing earnings including Kobe Steel and Yahoo Japan. Hang Seng (-2.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.6%) also slipped amid the escalation of trade tensions with underperformance in Hong Kong as protests continued and with a 500k-strong city-wide strike said to be planned which disrupted public transport and saw more than 130 flights cancelled, while the latest Hong Kong PMI data printed at a decade low due to the impact from the ongoing disorder and trade dispute. Furthermore, a miss in Chinese Caixin Services PMI added to the glum, with the selling exacerbated after the PBoC weakened the reference rate which pressured CNH to a record low against the greenback past the 7.0000 level seen by some to be a sticking-point for China and in turn, raised concerns of China weaponizing its currency. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven buying which saw 10yr JGB futures post a record high and the 10yr yield drop to its lowest in 3 years at around -0.2%, while T-notes also found support overnight and the BoJ were present in the market today under its massive bond buying program.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9225 (Prev. 6.8996)

PBoC said it can keep CNY basically stable and that depreciation of the currency is due to trade protectionism as well as tariffs on Chinese goods, while the PBoC added the FX market can find balance on its own and that China will crack down on short-term speculation of the CNY. (Newswires)

China is said to ask state buyers to halt their US agriculture imports. China’s US Ambassador said on Friday that if the US wants to talk about trade, then so will China, and if the US want to fight, so will China, while he added that new tariffs are an irrational and irresponsible act which Beijing will take new adequate countermeasures against. The Ambassador also commented on Hong Kong protests which he said are turning out to be violent as well as chaotic and should no longer be allowed to continue. (Newswires)

Subsequently, China State Planner says US' accusations that China has not bought US farm products are false, reported via State Media: 2mln tonnes of US soybeans heading to China will be loaded this month, Chinese firms have applied for tariff exemptions on various US agricultural products purchased since July and the US and China agreed that China will buy 14mln tonnes of soybeans from the US. (Newswires)

Protests continued in Hong Kong in which police fired tear gas into protesters over the weekend, while Hong Kong authorities expect flight cancellations and other transport disruptions as 500k protesters plan a city-wide strike. Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said protests have brought Hong Kong to the edge and protesters are pushing it to an extremely dangerous situation, while she added she will remain in her job to try and restore order. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Police says there is no chance of deploying People's Liberation Army (PLA) officers in protests. (Newswires) Most recently, reported that Beijing are to announce 'something new' regarding Hong Kong on Tuesday, an official has stated that Beijing's position is largely unchanged., SCMP citing a source

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Jul) 51.6 vs. Exp. 52.0 (Prev. 52.0); 5-month low Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Jul) 50.9 (Prev. 50.6) Hong Kong PMI (Jul) 42.8 (Prev. 46.9); lowest since 2009.

US

US President Trump is to address the nation on Monday (10:00 ET) and suggested that more gun control may be needed following a mass shooting incident in El Paso, Texas in which 20 were killed, while there was also a mass shooting in Dayton, Ohio. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iran reportedly seized an Iraq oil tanker that was allegedly smuggling fuel in the Gulf, although the Iraq Oil Minister denied any links to the tanker. (Newswires)

Turkey plans to carry out an operation east of the Euphrates in Syria, while US and Russia have been notified. (Newswires)

Pakistan says they will exercise all possible options after India have revoked special status for the Kashmir region. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson pledged GBP 1.8bln to upgrade 20 hospitals as part of meeting his Brexit pledges. In related news, PM Johnson’s most senior aide Dominic Cummings told ministers and officials Johnson will honour his October 31st pledge even if Jeremy Corbyn and pro-Remain Conservatives succeed in forcing a general election. (Newswires/Telegraph) Subsequently, MP Dominic Grieve a Tory rebel states there are a number of things the House of Commons could do, including bringing down the government and setting up a new one in its place; though this would rely on UK PM Johnson resigning after losing a no-confidence vote. (BBC)

Companies have switched a near-record amount of GBP deposits into foreign currency as part of contingency plans before a no-deal Brexit as it emerged that the government has built up a war chest to protect the pound, according to BoE figures. (Times)

US President Trump’s administration are reportedly warning the UK that it will not receive a free trade deal unless a digital services tax is dropped before it is scheduled to become law in the autumn budget; to be effective as of April 2020. (Sky/Telegraph) 

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Jul) 53.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)

- EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Jul) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.5)

- German Markit Services PMI (Jul) 54.5 vs. Exp. 55.4 (Prev. 55.4)

- German Markit Comp Final PMI (Jul) 50.9 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4)

 

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Jul) 51.4 vs. Exp. 50.2 (Prev. 50.2)

- UK Composite PMI (Jul) 50.7 (Prev. 49.7)

- PMI data suggests UK economy stagnated at the start of Q3

 

EQUITIES

Major European bourses have begun the week firmly in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.4%] following on from a downbeat Asia-Pac handover after market sentiment took a hit from dwindling trade hopes as China asked state-run purchasers to halt US farm goods imports. Additionally, the collapse of the CNH to 7.0+ status vs. the USD also added further jitters to the trade-sensitive sentiment. Indices are firmly in the red but have crawled off lows in recent trade after China State Planner dismissed President Trump’s accusation that China has not bought US farm goods, adding that US and China agreed to China will purchase 14mln tonnes of soybeans from the US, with 2mln to be loaded in August. Sectors are in the red across the board with some mild resilience in defensive sectors. To the downside, miners fare the worst amid the freefall in base metal prices due to a bleaker demand outlook in the sector as protectionism ramps up. Thus, ArcelorMittal (-4.5%), Antofagasta (-3.3%), Rio Tinto (-2.4%), and Anglo American (-3.5%) have all fallen to the foot of their respective bourses. However, Fresnillo (+4.0%) bucks the miners’ trend as the Co. benefits from the safe-haven surge in gold prices. European luxury names and the auto sectors are also bearing the brunt of the US-China trade spat with LVMH (-2.9%), Kering (-2.1%), Volkswagen (-2.7%), Daimler (-2.5%), BMW (-2.4%) and Peugeot (-3.1%) all lower as a result. In terms of individual movers HSBC (-1.0%) shares opened lower due to the surprise stepping-down of CEO Flint, despite improvements in its metrics and the announcement of a share buyback program. 

FX

AUD - The Aussie has been hit particularly hard by the Yuan’s slide through 7.0000 vs the Greenback on and offshore after the PBoC raised its official mid-point fix to 6.9225 overnight from 6.8996 last Friday. However, the sharp Cny and Cnh depreciation was sparked by reports that China has halted US agricultural produce purchases in retaliation to President Trump’s fresh tariff threat, with a softer than expected Caixin services PMI not helping as the composite PMI hit a 5 month low and Hong Kong’s headline print plunged to 42.8. All this undermining broad risk sentiment and base metals like iron or, with Aud/Usd dipping under 0.6750 at worst in the run up to the RBA policy meeting overnight with options pricing in a 50 pip break even that could expose the early January 0.6715 flash crash low if the Bank firmly flags more easing after a widely anticipated pause this time round – see the headline feed and/or Research Suite for a full preview.

NZD/CAD/GBP - Also victims of heightened risk aversion amidst rising US-China trade tensions, with the Kiwi down though 0.6500 at one stage vs its US peer, but holding up a bit better than the Aussie ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ rate decision that is unanimously forecast to result in the OCR being cut by a further 25 bp to 1.25%, mainly due to supportive cross-winds as Aud/Nzd reverses through 1.0400 again. Meanwhile, the Loonie is back below 1.3200 against the backdrop of retreating crude prices and with trading volumes impaired by Canada’s Civic holiday, but the Pound has gleaned some support from another UK PMI beat and by a greater margin in services compared to manufacturing and construction. Indeed, Cable has bounced from close to 1.2100 and Eur/Gbp stopped just shy of 0.9200, though remains elevated on persistent no deal Brexit concerns.

CHF/JPY/EUR - In stark contrast to the above, and to the overall detriment of the US Dollar (DXY losing more post-NFP momentum and sub-98.000) the Franc, Yen and Euro are all outperforming on safe-haven grounds, with Usd/Jpy probing through 106.00 and beneath a key Fib (106.06) that could be crucial on a closing basis. Usd/Chf is under 0.9750 and Eur/Usd has rebounded firmly to 1.1150 from 1.1105 even though Eur/Chf has fallen further below 1.0900 towards 1.0850 amidst mixed Eurozone services PMIs and a bleak Sentix survey.

EM - Regional currencies are generally weaker vs the Buck on the aforementioned risk-off environment, but once again the Try is holding up better than rivals within a 5.5490-6175 range as the Lira responds favourably to Turkish inflation data that was not as strong as expected, plus the CBRT’s RRR moves that will culminate in a net Usd2.1 bn liquidity drain.

CBRT says RRR for FX deposits/participation fund have been increased by 100bps for all maturity brackets, remuneration rate for USD-denominated RR,Reserve options and Free Reserves held at the CBRT had been decreased by 100bps. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Fixed remains firm. but off best levels after a rather mixed am data slate, with the surprise services PMI prints largely arising from Germany where both the Composite and Services readings were revised down, to 50.9 and 54.4 (Prev. 51.4 and 55.4); although these had little to no impact on Bunds given the overriding geopolitical, trade and Central Bank narrative at present. The core EZ bond is still underpinned on the aforementioned factors, but has slipped somewhat from session/contract highs at 176.62 (176.30 last), with perhaps some technical resistance halting further advances for now at least given 176.73 & 85 levels flagged on certain charts. Elsewhere in the EZ, the PMIs for Italy and France were encouraging though the EZ wide release was dented somewhat by Germany and a Spanish miss vs consensus. Meanwhile, the UK survey saw services continue the run of better than forecast headline readings, but IHS/Markit suggests that the UK economy stagnated at the start of Q3, ahead of this Friday’s official ONS data for Q2 and the month of June. However, Gilts were largely unaffected, and actually continued to grind higher to 134.31 at best (+82 ticks), as USTs lead bond drive, albeit down from overnight peaks and the curve not quite as flat ahead of the Services PMI (Final) and ISM Non-Manufacturing metrics.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are on the backfoot due to the prospect of lower global demand amid the seemingly widening gap between US and China in trade, in turn souring sentiment. WTI now straddles north of the USD 55/bbl mark while its Brent counterpart has just reclaimed USD 61/bbl after finding a base below the round figure. Looking ahead, tomorrow sees the release of the EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook, followed by the IEA Monthly Oil Report on Friday. Elsewhere, metals markets were rattled by the latest developments in the US-China saga with spot gold jumping over 1% to a peak of 1459/oz, the highest level in six years. Meanwhile, copper prices slumped to a 2-year low, but have since crawled off lows, with the red metal increasingly threatening USD 2.5/lb to the downside. Finally, Dalian Iron ore futures hit limit down after crumbling over 6% after declining below USD 100/tonne amid demand woes from the aforementioned US-China fallout, which was exacerbated by rising stockpiles of the raw material.

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih spoke to Russia Energy Minister Novak about oil markets and stressed the kingdom would continue to comply with output cuts until the end of Q1 2020. (Twitter)

UAE's ADNOC sets July Murban crude official selling price at USD 66.15/bbl, +USD 1.35/bbl from June. (Newswires)

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures gap up ahead of UK services PMI
content: In line with core counterparts, UK debt and STIR contracts have rebounded firmly from post-NFP lows as risk sentiment sours on the latest deterioration in US-China trade relations among various other negative factors. The 10 year benchmark opened at 134.01 vs its previous 133.49 settlement price and 133.85 contract high before extending gains to 72 ticks at 134.21, at best, while the 3 month strip advanced 1-6 ticks in early trade. Ahead, services PMI and the composite reading that will provide IHS/Markit with its first indication of how GDP started Q3 after stagnation in the last quarter.

Bunds: bulls back in the driving seat after post-NFP reversal
content: The bond market rally has resumed after Friday’s brief pull-back in wake of broadly upbeat US labour data, as US-China trade wars escalate and rekindle strong demand for safe-haven assets, like Gold and zero/relatively low-risk debt. Bunds have been as high as 176.62, with the corresponding yield clearly through -50 bp and its UST equivalent heading towards 1.75% ahead of the EU cash bourse opens that could easily spark another round of buying if risk aversion accelerates. Eurozone services PMIs and Sentix are due, but unlikely to warrant much attention given the current focus on global protectionism, geopolitics and perceived implications for Central Bank policy.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Axel Springer (SPR GY) – KKR’s offer for the Co. has now attained the minimum acceptance level. (Newswires)

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

5th August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were lower across the board as the stock rout resumed from last week’s shock tariff announcement by US President Trump and with retaliation from China in which it asked state-run purchasers to halt US agriculture imports, while a collapse in the CNH through the 7.00 handle also exacerbated the risk averse tone. ASX 200 (-1.7%) weakened with the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials front-running the declines, although gold names bucked the trend on the precious metal’s safe-haven status, while Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) was pressured by a firmer currency and several disappointing earnings including Kobe Steel and Yahoo Japan which shares have suffered a double-digit percentage drop. Hang Seng (-2.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) also slipped amid the escalation of trade tensions with underperformance in Hong Kong as protests continued and with a 500k-strong city-wide strike said to be planned which disrupted public transport and saw more than 130 flights cancelled, while the latest Hong Kong PMI data printed at a decade low due to the impact from the ongoing disorder and trade dispute. Furthermore, a miss in Chinese Caixin Services PMI added to the glum, with the selling exacerbated after the PBoC weakened the reference rate which pressured CNH to a record low against the greenback past the 7.0000 level seen by some to be a sticking-point for China and in turn, raised concerns of China weaponizing its currency.

FTSE 100

HSBC (HSBA LN) - H1 adj. pre-tax profit USD 12.5bln vs. Prev. USD 11.7bln Y/Y. Adj. revenue USD 29.4bln vs. Prev. USD 27.3bln Y/Y. Co. announced a share buyback of up to USD 1.0bln of shares. CET1 ratio 14.3% vs. Prev. 14.3% Q/Q. ROTE 11.2% vs. Prev. 9.7% Y/Y. Net interest income USD 8.14bln vs. Prev. USD 5.46bln. Net interest margin 1.61% vs. Prev. 1.66% Y/Y. CEO Flint steps down and Noel Quinn is named interim CEO. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) – A strike planned by Unite members working at Heathrow airport has been called off to allow further talks over a pay dispute. The strike was previously set to begin today. (BBC/Guardian)

Schroders (SDR LN)/ Jupiter Fund Management (JUP LN) – Hedge funds have been increasing short positions against Cos amid an increasing prospect of a no-deal Brexit. Steve Cohen’s Point72 hedge fund took out a 0.51% short position in Schroders and increased its short position in Jupiter to 1.23%, (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co. is to divest its BT Fleet Solutions unit to AURELIUS, terms undisclosed. (Newswires)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – Denmark has accused the Co. of failing to pay over GBP 100mln in taxes after its 2012 HQ shift to London from Copenhagen. (Times)

Telecom Names – UK Telecom Industry has written an open letter to UK PM Johnson stating that the PM’s pledge of fibre broadband for all by 2025 is possible, but only if specific issues are resolved in the next year: planning reform, impact of fibre tax, new builds provision and skills shortage. (BBC)

Pension Names – UK Work & Pensions Committee have called on the government to undertake immediate action against pension funds which fail to disclose the amount they charge to savers; calling on Co’s implementing excessive charges to be charged accusing them of ‘misinforming, mischarging and overcharging’ savings. (Guardian/Times)

Gambling Names – A survey indicates that the ‘when the fun stops, stop’ warning message seen with gambling adverts has no significant effect on gambling behaviour. (Guardian)

UK firms – Government figures indicate that the majority of firms which export only to the EU do not have the relevant paperwork to continue as normal in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

 

Cobham (COB LN) – Family behind the Co. have warned that the USD 4bln takeover deal by Advent International may put the UK’s defence and national security at risk, stating that Advent’s assurances over the protection of skills and jobs are to be taken with caution. (Telegraph)

Reckitt Benckiser (RB/ LN) – Co. have begun a JV with Founders Factory, with the intention of investing in 10 new start ups and 25 existing businesses. (Telegraph)

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Fosun, who are in discussions to purchase the Co., have outlined plans to attract Chinese tourists to European holiday destinations. (Newswires)

Oil names - Oil prices subdued as markets were spooked by the escalation in the US-China trade war and depreciation of the CNY. This saw oil WTI decline more than 1% although the downside has been stemmed by support at the USD 55.00/bbl level. (RANsquawk)

Mining names - Gold prices were boosted above USD 1450/oz as the precious metal benefitted from its safe-haven status as well as a weaker greenback, while copper was dragged amid the sell-off in stocks and with pressure seen in Chinese commodity prices in which iron prices tumbled around 3% shortly after the open of Shanghai metals trade. (RANsquawk)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 5th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were lower across the board as the stock rout resumed from last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump
  • China has asked state-run purchasers to halt US agriculture imports, while a collapse in the CNH through the 7.00 handle also exacerbated the risk-averse tone
  • DXY slightly softened and dipped below 98.00, whilst safe-haven flows pressured USD/JPY below 106.00 for the first time since the flash crash at the beginning of the year
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK & US Services and Composite PMI; US ISM-Non-Manufacturing PMI; New Zealand Unemployment
  • Earnings: Linde, Pirelli & HSBC

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lower across the board as the stock rout resumed from last week’s tariff announcement by US President Trump and with retaliation from China in which it asked state-run purchasers to halt US agriculture imports, while a collapse in the CNH through the 7.00 handle also exacerbated the risk averse tone. ASX 200 (-1.7%) weakened with the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials front-running the declines, although gold names bucked the trend on the precious metal’s safe-haven status, while Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) was pressured by a firmer currency and several disappointing earnings including Kobe Steel and Yahoo Japan. Hang Seng (-2.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) also slipped amid the escalation of trade tensions with underperformance in Hong Kong as protests continued and with a 500k-strong city-wide strike said to be planned which disrupted public transport and saw more than 130 flights cancelled, while the latest Hong Kong PMI data printed at a decade low due to the impact from the ongoing disorder and trade dispute. Furthermore, a miss in Chinese Caixin Services PMI added to the glum, with the selling exacerbated after the PBoC weakened the reference rate which pressured CNH to a record low against the greenback past the 7.0000 level seen by some to be a sticking-point for China and in turn, raised concerns of China weaponizing its currency. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven buying which saw 10yr JGB futures post a record high and the 10yr yield drop to its lowest in 3 years at around -0.2%, while T-notes also found support overnight and the BoJ were present in the market today under its massive bond buying program.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9225 (Prev. 6.8996)

 

PBoC said it can keep CNY basically stable and that depreciation of the currency is due to trade protectionism as well as tariffs on Chinese goods, while the PBoC added the FX market can find balance on its own and that China will crack down on short-term speculation of the CNY. (Newswires)

 

US President Trump said US has to have a better deal, not an even deal with China and that China has a lot to do to turn things around, while he also stated that he can always raise tariffs and China's currency is "going to hell". (Newswires/Twitter)

 

China is said to ask state buyers to halt their US agriculture imports. China’s US Ambassador said on Friday that if the US wants to talk about trade, then so will China, and if the US want to fight, so will China, while he added that new tariffs are an irrational and irresponsible act which Beijing will take new adequate countermeasures against. The Ambassador also commented on Hong Kong protests which he said are turning out to be violent as well as chaotic and should no longer be allowed to continue. (Newswires)

 

Protests continued in Hong Kong in which police fired tear gas into protesters over the weekend, while Hong Kong authorities expect flight cancellations and other transport disruptions as 500k protesters plan a city-wide strike. Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said protests have brought Hong Kong to the edge and protesters are pushing it to an extremely dangerous situation, while she added she will remain in her job to try and restore order. (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Jul) 51.6 vs. Exp. 52.0 (Prev. 52.0); 5-month low Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Jul) 50.9 (Prev. 50.6) Hong Kong PMI (Jul) 42.8 (Prev. 46.9); lowest since 2009.

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson pledged GBP 1.8bln to upgrade 20 hospitals as part of meeting his Brexit pledges. In related news, PM Johnson’s most senior aide Dominic Cummings told ministers and officials Johnson will honour his October 31st pledge even if Jeremy Corbyn and pro-Remain Conservatives succeed in forcing a general election. (Newswires/Telegraph) Subsequently, MP Dominic Grieve a Tory rebel states there are a number of things the House of Commons could do, including bringing down the government and setting up a new one in its place; though this would rely on UK PM Johnson resigning after losing a no-confidence vote. (BBC)

Companies have switched a near-record amount of GBP deposits into foreign currency as part of contingency plans before a no-deal Brexit as it emerged that the government has built up a war chest to protect the pound, according to BoE figures. (Times)

US President Trump’s administration are reportedly warning the UK that it will not receive a free trade deal unless a digital services tax is dropped before it is scheduled to become law in the autumn budget; to be effective as of April 2020. (Sky/Telegraph)

US President Trump confirmed he will sign a beef agreement with EU which will make it easier for US firms to export to the EU and result in a 46% increase in US exports of beef to the EU. In other news, US President Trump said EU auto tariffs are never off the table and that if he doesn't get what he wants, he'll have no choice but to put on auto tariffs. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Greece at 'BB-'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires) 

FX

 

The greenback slightly softened and dipped below 98.00, although its major transatlantic counterparts failed to take advantage amid the widespread risk averse tone with EUR/USD and GBP/USD choppy at the 1.1100 and 1.2100 handles respectively. Conversely, JPY strengthened on safe-haven flows which pressured USD/JPY to below 106.00 for the first time since the flash crash at the beginning of the year, while USD/CNY surged above the psychological key 7.0000 level for the first time since the GFC and USD/CNH printed a record high at the 7.1100 handle after a softer reference rate setting by the PBoC which further spooked investor sentiment due to concerns of China weaponizing its currency in the trade war with the US. However, the PBoC later attributed the depreciation of the currency to trade protectionism, as well as tariffs on Chinese goods, and stated it will crack down on short-term speculation of the CNY. Antipodeans were weighed due to their high-beta properties and heavy China exposure, with participants weary ahead of the heavy slate of central bank activity this week including policy decisions from the RBA and RBNZ. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with oil prices subdued as markets were spooked by the escalation in the US-China trade war and depreciation of the CNY. This saw oil WTI decline more than 1% although the downside has been stemmed by support at the USD 55.00/bbl level, with Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih also reiterating to comply with output cuts to Q1 next year during a discussion with Russia Energy Minister Novak. Elsewhere, gold prices were boosted above USD 1450/oz as the precious metal benefitted from its safe-haven status as well as a weaker greenback, while copper was dragged amid the sell-off in stocks and with pressure seen in Chinese commodity prices in which iron prices tumbled around 3% shortly after the open of Shanghai metals trade. 

Baker Hughes Oil rigs -6 at 770, nat gas rigs +2 at 171, total rigs -4 at 942. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih spoke to Russia Energy Minister Novak about oil markets and stressed the kingdom would continue to comply with output cuts until the end of Q1 2020. (Twitter)

GEOPOLITICS

Satellite imagery reportedly showed minimal activity around North Korea's Yongbyon nuclear complex with some evidence of probable continued operations of the Uranium Enrichment Plant, while there were also reports that North Korea said it has never agreed on limiting missile distance. (Newswires)

Iran reportedly seized an Iraq oil tanker that was allegedly smuggling fuel in the Gulf, although the Iraq Oil Minister denied any links to the tanker. (Newswires)

Turkey plans to carry out an operation east of the Euphrates in Syria, while US and Russia have been notified. (Newswires) 

US

The yield curve flattened, taking its cue from escalating trade escalations, shrugging-off a generally upbeat payrolls report. Markets have now fully priced a September rate cut, and have 100bps of easing priced through the end of 2020 (note, in wake of the payrolls report, it was roughly 70bps priced, which suggests that traders have added to their easing expectations in wake of the trade escalation. At settlement, major curve spreads were narrower. US T-note (U9) futures settled 5+ ticks higher at 128-27+.

US President Trump is to address the nation on Monday and suggested that more gun control may be needed following a mass shooting incident in El Paso, Texas in which 20 were killed, while there was also a mass shooting in Dayton, Ohio. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Voter, hawk) explained her dissent at Wednesday's FOMC in which she stated the moderation in the economy was in line with her outlook at the start of the year, while she added there are risks to her outlook and will be data dependent in shaping her outlook. (Newswires)

HSBC (5 HK) - Co. H1 adj. pre-tax profit USD 12.5bln vs. Prev. USD 11.7bln Y/Y, Adj. rev. USD 29.4bln vs. Prev. USD 27.3bln Y/Y, Co. announces to buyback up to USD 1.0bln of shares, while CEO Flint steps down and Noel Quinn is named interim CEO

Protests

Protests continued in Hong Kong again in which police fired tear gas into protesters over the weekend, while Hong Kong authorities expect flight cancellations and other transport disruptions as 500k protesters plan a city-wide strike. There were comments from the Hong Kong government that illegal protests are pushing the city to extremely dangerous edge and Chief Executive Lam will be meeting the press today, while China stated it will not allow the situation to persist. (Newswires) 

Trade

US President Trump said US has to have a better deal, not an even deal with China and that China has a lot to do to turn things around, while he also stated that he can always raise tariffs and China's currency is "going to hell". (Newswires/Twitter)

There were initial reports that US President Trump is willing to shelve China tariffs if China takes positive action, according to CNBC's Tausche citing a senior admin official. However, NEC Director Kudlow later stated he has not heard anything definitive about a possibility of China tariff delays and that US President Trump is not satisfied with progress in talks. Furthermore, Kudlow stated that a number of good things could happen in the month prior to tariffs going on Chinese goods and that good things could arise from the September meeting between US and China. (Newswires/CNBC/Fox)

China said on Friday it would not “give an inch” by offering trade concessions to the United States and promised to retaliate if US President Trump went ahead with imposing further tariffs. (SCMP)

China’s US Ambassador said if the US wants to talk about trade, then so will China, and if the US want to fight, so will China, while he added that new tariffs are an irrational and irresponsible act which Beijing will take new adequate countermeasures against. The Ambassador also commented on Hong Kong protests which he said are turning out to be violent as well as chaotic and should no longer be allowed to continue. (Newswires)

China's Global Times Editor said the Chinese side always has a second plan B including a series of counter measures and that Beijing is very disappointed by the latest "flip-flops of the US", while he quoted a well-informed official as saying "China won't fight the battle unprepared”. (Twitter)

Other News

PBoC will comprehensively use multiple monetary policy tools in H2 and maintain prudent monetary policy, while it will strengthen counter cyclical adjustments and lower RRR at an appropriate time. PBoC will also continue interest rate and exchange rate reform, as well as keep liquidity reasonably ample. (Newswires)
